responses.content: Replay of today's conference call will remain available on the investor relations website for the next 24 hours.

Q4 beat guidance, total revenue grew 11%, cloud revenue grew 27%, and RPO climbed to $138B. The cloud applications and infrastructure businesses are accelerating, and we raised FY26 revenue guidance to over $67B with cloud revenue expected to grow faster than 40%.

OCI infrastructure revenue was up 52% while consumption revenue grew 62%, and contracted bookings continue to outstrip supply. Customers are scaling Oracle Autonomous Database and the AI Data Platform, which is why OCI revenue should grow over 70% in FY26.

Capex in the quarter hit $21.2B because we are deploying revenue-generating equipment into data centers and accelerating capacity to match an enormous backlog. FY26 CapEx will likely exceed $25B as we continue to satisfy demand.

Oracle controls the stack from silicon-to-cloud to applications. The Autonomous Database powers the OCI stack, delivering higher security, reliability, and automation that other hyperscalers can't match.

Oracle is building the largest number of cloud data centers, bringing Database 23AI to every cloud including partners' clouds, and embedding AI agents across ERP/EPM/supply chain suites to modernize back-office operations.

questions.question_text: Can you help investors understand the durability and profitability of Oracle's AI business and how your database differentiates the stack?
Is Stargate part of the >70% IaaS growth target and how should we think about RPO climbing more than 100% in FY26?
CapEx came in much higher than expectations—what was it spent on, how is it tied to revenue, and why is $25B the right run rate for FY26?
What are customers saying about migrating the database to the cloud, and how are cloud database revenues contributing to the projected >70% OCI growth?
Fusion applications are growing 22%—what is driving that acceleration and how do AI agents factor into the application story?
Why does having the full stack—from apps to database to infrastructure—matter now that AI and new computing paradigms are accelerating?
